conclusion: For an ideal gas, the rate at which molecules strike 1 m² of the container wall is proportional to the pressure P divided by the square-root of the temperature T: R ∝ P/√T.
Process C → D is isothermal, so T is constant.
Along an isotherm for a fixed amount of gas, PV = constant, so when the piston is pushed in from C to D, the volume decreases and the pressure increases.
Because T does not change, the collision rate varies directly with the pressure.
Therefore, as the system moves from C to D, the pressure rises and the number of molecular impacts per unit area per unit time rises in the same proportion.
From state C to state D, the gas temperature remains constant while the pressure increases, so the number of molecules striking each unit area of the wall per unit time increases accordingly.
